Clinical: Aphthae. Diarrhoea. Digestion, slow. Haemorrhoids. Nymphomania. Pruritus vulvae.
Characteristics: Ferula has been proved, but I am not aware of any clinical experience with it. Heat and burning are produced in most parts, and sensations of coldness in others. Stiffness and constriction were also prominent. Violent sexual excitement in women. A cough was complained of, < in damp or cold weather.
Relations: Compare: Other Umbelliferae; tongue as if burnt, Sang. c.
Head: Burning in head.
Icy coldness in occiput during day.
Lancinations, pricking, pulling pains in occiput.
Nose: Redness of nose; sensitive to touch.
Scabs in nose, with smarting and itching.
Mouth: Aphthae; heat in mouth; sensation in tongue as if burnt.
Throat: Scratching, burning, lancinations; difficulty of swallowing.
Stomach: Heat and cutting pains in stomach; < after eating.
Stool and Anus: Haemorrhoids, with itching, burning, lancinating, and prickings at anus.
Diarrhoea day and night, but worse by day; stools light-yellow and watery, with smarting and burning at anus.
Female Sexual Organs: Menses several days early, more profuse, thin or thick, with heat and itching of vulva.
Respiratory Organs: Cough dry or loose, < in damp or cold weather, with thick yellow expectoration.
Heart: Constriction and heat at heart; beats stronger.
Upper Limbs: Stiffness of arms; difficulty in bending them.
Lower Limbs: Cold feeling along sciatic nerves; felt soon after rising up.
Lancination along nerves of thighs and legs.
Skin: Small red pimples and incessant itching.
Red pimples with white tips in beard and whiskers.
Pricking and violent itching in many parts, < at night.
Sleep: Sleepy in day; sleepless; restless; starting from sleep at night.
